Detailed Description

Flow of control with data flow graph representation

The DFG threads inherits from the the RFO threads the structure of stack of frames of closures to implement the reference order of execution of closures. Once a DFG thread is started, it execute all its closures with respect to this order. If a closure is in state WAITING (for a non data flow constraint), the thread is suspended as a RFO thread.

The DFG thread organizes its stack of frames of closures with dataflow dependencies between tasks. Dependencies are linked with the chain of access that several tasks require to access to a global data. A closure is ready for execution by the thread that creates it iff

  • the closure is the next closure to execute
  • the closure may have transition INIT -> EXEC In case the state is WAINTING, the DFG thread suspend itself until its states is not in state WAITING. In case the state is TERM, the DFG thread executes only the terminaison code for the closure (method release of its format). In case the state is STEAL, the DFG thread executes only the merge code for the closure (method merge of its format).

The DFG thread differs from the RFO thread in the way to steal a closure :

  • when a steal request arrives on a victim dfg thread, the method original_steal (for reification) is invoked. The method iterates to the list of stacks with respect to their creation order and evalutes several condition to steal a closure :
    • C1(clo) = is the closure clo stealable ?
    • C2(clo) = is the closure clo ready ? If both C1 et C2 are true the caller try to change the state of the closure to the state INIT assuming the initial state is INIT. See the state diagram of closures. The most important evaluation is C2(clo) to compute the readiness of the closure. This evaluation try to propagate the readiness of accesses that hanle closures.
